Founder/President at Qonto, where I run product and operations • Founded Smok.io (acquired) • COO at Groupon EMEA/APAC • INSEAD and EPFL alumnus
Apr 13

From founder to product owner

My last 11 months as a product owner

Building a world-class product is an end in itself. It determines the future success of the company, not only because that’s what customers are going to pay for but also because it will enable sales, marketing and customer success to have the maximum impact. Think about Michael Schumacher: would that have been possible for him to win 7 times the F1 world championship without a perfect car? I don’t think so.

At the end of the day, building a company is about hiring talented people to build a great product to generate revenue. Period. So building a product is really an end in itself.

When Alex and I decided to build Qonto, we quickly agreed that I would focus on product and operations. None of us had the full knowledge to endorse the product owner position, yet I was very attracted by what the job meant in terms of vision, stake at play and day-to-day work.

Here are my 2 cents on how I led Product at Qonto with limited experience as a product owner.

The mindset 🙇

A user only knows what she thinks she wants based on her own experience… with current solutions.

Banking is an old dusty industry where all players’ products look alike. We rapidly understood that reinventing online banking would require to go beyond what the customers think to be true in terms of features and user experience.

When you start a product from scratch, you have no customers and hence limited data available to objectify your product choices. With no data, I forced myself to figure out how business banking should work if it were invented today rather than trying to improve an existing platform which would distract us from fixing the real pain points.

In the end, designing a product from scratch is mainly about trusting yourself in making the right decisions. I like to break this journey into:

  • Knowledge: understand precisely which pains you are trying to solve and why it’s so important, and order them. This will predominantly be driven by your own experience and confirmed by running short survey with dozens of your friends (as of now, we have interviewed 120+ startups to confirm our features package). As your product goes live, you must add data to help you decide and prioritize.
  • Discipline & commitment: organize and prioritize the features based on your knowledge. Use the right tools to do that (can be Trello, can be Jira, can be Basecamp) and set a daily routine, to (i) formalize and (ii) test everything you think about.
  • Intuition: connect the dots with features implemented by players evolving outside of your sector, and see if you can transpose them in a relevant manner in your product. For example, we noticed that bank transactions behaved like emails: they are ordered by dates, they can have different states (draft, sent, received, bounced, etc) and what matter is the last transactions which occurred since your last connection. When we got that, we broke down how Gmail worked, and we extracted its logic which made sense for our product.
  • Courage: always build the case to convince the team about why you make decisions. Then focus on the what, with no looking back (for a certain time).

As our product will (publicly) go live over the coming weeks, I would probably add to the list above something like make your customers happy. There is no way our users, even friends, will stick around if we ignore their needs and their suggestions in terms of customer experience and do not fill their expectations; we cannot simply force them to use our product!

The homework 🤓

There are no real tricks or secret sauce here. The one skill that stands out when building an outstanding product is the ability to be and remain focused.

There are several ways to do that and I am personally a big fan of to-do lists that I write down every morning before kicking the day off!

My first high-level to-do list as a product owner is still relevant today.

  1. Listing the pain points you are trying to solve;
  2. Listing down your core features and write your specs as you go;
  3. Checking what could be your product range and pricing;
  4. Thinking about the impact on your team (including customer support, marketing and sales);
  5. Testing the competition; know why you stand out (in terms of experience, technology and product/market fit) and where you fail;
  6. Setting up or improving your everyday tools;
  7. Knowing the market;
  8. Learning about regulation (applicable to Qonto);
  9. And repeat…

As a product owner, you are going to be overwhelmed by questions and requests related to those topics, 12+ hours a day. Your team is going to be hyper dependent on your availability, and if you fail to show up, your company will fail.

So be prepared to know, and most importantly to be available to share this knowledge.

The setup 💼

I just love clean automated product management setups. This allows to stop thinking permanently about the how and to focus on the what. Our basic requirements were the following:

  • Log ideas, feedback and bugs as soon as possible (spend the time to automate connections between your different SaaS);
  • Make sure everybody is on the same page (at Qonto, we give access of everything to everyone);
  • Use the tools the team is going to accept: I would not say the team is completely in love with Jira 😭… but it does the job);
  • Prioritize: I use the priority flag in Jira, and automatically sort all stories so that urgent tickets stay at the top of the list without having to shuffle the backlog all day long);
  • Assign… but leave some freedom. We encourage initiative and the last thing we want is to only work top-down; on the other hand, allowing waterfalls create chaos and the company needs a clear formalized direction in order to move ahead;
  • Keep users in the loop: bug fix or features previously requested should be announced as soon as they are released.

Our product management process (see above) is pretty standard but efficient at the same time considering that it is almost fully automated. We are however always trying to improve and consequently are seriously thinking of re-working a few things:

  • Switching from Confluence to Nuclino (cleaner, simpler interface)
  • Moving from Jira to… ? (exploring a few things such as Zenhub)
  • Using exclusively InVision’s Inspector and Craft (and stop using Zeplin)

PS: drop me a line if you believe we are missing something critical!

The typical week 🏈

In addition to working on the product, my day-to-day job includes interviewing a lot of candidates, from engineers to designers to product owners. I constantly bump into candidates who have a naive vision of what the jobs could mean, usually this guy who ‘loves brainstorming, sticking post-it on a window and running focus groups’. Don’t get me wrong: those tasks are key and part of the job but they probably only represent 25% of it.

At the end of the day, it’s very important to keep in mind that:

  • The product owners’ missions are to write specs, stories and bug reports with input coming from testing, customer insight and formal/informal team ideas;
  • The product designers’ output is to design mock-ups with input coming from research, discussions and PM work;
  • The engineer’s output is to write code and document it with input coming from discussions and PM work.

Every day (in that order — non exhaustive)

  • Stand-up meeting
  • Write bug reports
  • Write user stories, classify them (UX-wow vs. market share) and re-prioritize (if needed)
  • Working session and hand checks with dev team
  • Design review
  • Clarify specs/documentation from service providers
  • QA (1 story = 1 github branch)

Every week (in that order — non exhaustive)

  • (Monday) Release new version
  • (Monday) Debrief sprint
  • (Monday) Launch new sprint
  • (Depends) Product meeting and Q&A

11 months later 🚀

We started to work on Qonto about 11 months ago and are starting to get a sense of what could make us a successful Fintech. One thing we probably have in common with all other startups out there is that we cannot settle… movimiento es la vida (cc Brad Pitt in World War Z). A great product today never lasts and that’s why great product owners have to keep thinking of improvements, from internal process to seemingly unimportant features.

My last words for today will go towards my dear colleagues: a full happy life comes from small sacrifices.

Be patient, listen well, keep learning, value great work, and trust your growth potential.

You do not need any diploma to perform those tasks; just passion and motivation. This is probably what “saved” me as a first-time product owner.

Special thank you to Anh-Tho for proof reading this article.
